background: A water company allocates its total water supply into two types of bottles, glass, and plastic, with differing capacities and customer preferences influencing production ratios.
constraints: Number of glass bottles is non-negative
Number of plastic bottles is non-negative
The sum of the water in all bottles does not exceed TotalWaterVolume ml
The number of plastic bottles is at least RatioPlasticToGlass times the number of glass bottles
There must be at least MinGlassBottles glass bottles
objective: Maximize the total number of bottles produced
description: A water company sells water in glass and plastic bottles. A glass bottle can hold \param{VolumeGlass} ml of water while a plastic bottle can hold \param{VolumePlastic} ml of water. Because most customer prefer plastic bottles, the number of plastic bottles must be at least \param{RatioPlasticToGlass} times the number of glass bottles. However, there must be at least \param{MinGlassBottles} glass bottles. If the company has available \param{TotalWaterVolume} ml of water, how many of each bottle should be made to maximize the total number of bottles?

parameters.definition: Volume of water that a glass bottle can hold
Volume of water that a plastic bottle can hold
The minimum ratio of the number of plastic bottles to the number of glass bottles
Minimum number of glass bottles that must be produced
